item.title: The Wild Hunt Challenge 2023
item.description:
The Golden One issued his Wild Hunt challenge for 2023 a while back and I intend to take part.

The challenge(s) for this year (like all years) are to make positive changes in your life by getting more organised, being more well read and improving your health. Of course the Glorious Lion’s challenge includes going to the gym. I will go over each challenge, my thoughts on them and how I intended to approach them.

Challenge One - Notebook

The first part of the challenge is probably the most important as it will assist with the remainder of the challenges as well as being immensely useful for everyday organisiation in general.

The challenge is simple, get a notebook and use it. Particular instruction on how to use it was given which is pretty straightforward. Write down what you plan to day on each given day and tick them off as you go. You get a feeling of accomplishment as you do this and get to see how you progress, where improvements can be made and you can keep on top of things such that you don’t forget anything.

This is a great start to the challenge, a fairly reasonable introductory step that prepares you for the rest. Not much to say about it other than it being useful for the rest of the challenge.

Challenge Two - Read A Book

Part two of the challenge is to read a book, the recommended text is The Golden One’s own book Dauntless: Wild Hunt Edition, which I intend to read for this challenge as I have been meaning to get around to reading it anyway.

When presenting this part of the challenge the suggestion of reading a classic is also given and this is used to explain the purpose of the challenge. Reading a book doesn’t just teach you what its contents are, it also teaches you the world view of the author, the writing style used, why the book was written and you may even develop an idea as to why someone would want to read the book. A great intellectual exercise.

As mentioned I plan to read Dauntless for this challenge. I already own a copy, as an additional challenge I plan to review the book and give my thoughts on it. I will consider this part of the challenge complete when I do so.

Challenge Three - The Temple of Iron

Next we have a challenge relating to The Temple of Iron, which if you are unfamiliar is a term that Gigachads use to refer to the gym. In particular the challenge is to adopt a schedule for the gym and stick to it.

Pretty straightforward, the purpose of this challenge is to instill discipline as well as to get you in the gym and lifting. Which is glorious.

The Golden One gives Smolov Jr. as an example of a schedule / routine but I plan to use Starting Strength as it is what I prefer.

Challenge Four - Meditation

The fourth part of the challenge is to start meditating, every day. Starting at ten minutes with a guided meditation method. The recommended routine is the Wim Hof routine. I don’t know anything about it yet but I’ll try to take the advice and at least look into it.

There’s not much else to say here, I don’t know much about meditation to really comment on it at this stage.

Challenge Five - Fasting

The final challenge is to do a twenty four hour fast. There are many advantages to fasting, from appetite control, developing your discipline, autophagy and weight loss. There are many others but these are the four most common and most directly useful to myself.

This is likely to be the easiest part of the challenge for me as I already practice rolling fasting as a means of weight loss. I will say that it is very effective and if there are other benefits (there most certainly is) they will creep their way in. You aren’t going to wake up after your first fast to find all the benefits occurred overnight.

I recommend fasting alongside a ketogenic diet. Or at the very least a ketogenic protocol prior to the fast.

My Approach

The following is my appraoch or how I intend to approach each challenge:

  1. I purchases a nice Oxford Touch notebook featuring 90gsm paper. Perfect for writing on both sides of.
    • There is nothing fancy about it really, it’s a normal notebook with no thrills.
    • I didn’t see much point in getting anything nicer than this for keeping checklists.
  2. As mentioned above I will be reading Dauntless.
  3. Starting Strength is a great routine for building strength, I switch between it and StrongLifts every so often.
    • I also add in significant cardio work as well.
  4. I will start off with the recommended Wim Hof routine and see how it goes.
    • This is the only challenge I see being somewhat of a change of pace / new experience.
  5. I already have at least a twenty four hour fast every week.
    • Sometimes I throw in a forty eight or seventy two hour fast.
    • I do not consent to calories!

Comments

Now that I have given a breakdown of the challenge and my thoughts on each part I have a few comments on the overall challenge to make. First and foremost, the combination of these challenges will have obvious benefits to most people. I highly recommend taking part. Additionally you can modify it or add your own challenges if you’d like. The idea behind this is to make your New Year’s resolution more meaningful without calling it a New Year’s resolution. That’s a cringe name, we aren’t making “resolutions” we are COMPETING in the WILD HUNT with our leader THE GLORIOUS LION!

I will update this post occasionally with my thoughts on the challenges so far. Glory to those competing!

item.title: Necessary Evils on the Internet?
item.description:
The modern Internet experience for the average Internet user is a strange thing indeed. The compulsive desire to “check notis” is truly a technological horror and an expression of addictive behavior. Yet many find it to not only be “normal” but completely acceptable. How bizarre!

When I was younger and I wanted to talk to my friends online I had to open various chat applications to be able to communicate with them all because everyone had just one application that they were comfortable with (or their parents allowed to be installed on the family computer) and it was normal for people to take days or weeks to reply.

Now it seems that is no longer the case, everyone feels some kind of need to be on every platform and expects instantaneous replies regardless of time zones or whether the recipient is awake or busy. It’s a very artificial way of interacting with people and it is quite disturbing to think about.

On the topic of being “on every platform”, I have come to resent the fact that I have started to rely on some of these same platforms myself recently. Although I have been doing this so far without accounts on them (shout out to nitter!). This makes it very time consuming and exhausting to keep up to date with people that use these platforms exclusively.

Unfortunately there is no realistic solution to this problem when you want to follow more than five or so accounts. Which is why I have recently started to think that it may be a necessary evil to create an account on these platforms for the purpose of following and keeping up to date with certain people, topics, etc.

Which goes against the spirit of what I am trying to do with this blog: being my own platform.

Is it a necessary evil or am I just unaware of a better solution?

I have tried to use fediverse in the past, and while technologically it is a neat technological solution to problems and some cool people are on there that I would like to keep up to date with it falls into the same category of click-chasing habit forming behavior that twitter, etc all infect their users with.

For now I haven’t made accounts on these platforms however it is something that I am starting to think about. ü§î

Update

I have decided to try it out and see for myself if it is worth the hassle. You can follow me @Dunkelheitxyz if you want to. As I mentioned above I intend to just use it to keep up to date with some accounts that don’t have or use alternatives.

Update 2

I am not impressed with the twitter experience at all. It seems like it has gotten worse over the years. Which would surprise me if I didn’t expect this. The issues I pointed out in past posts about the issues being what twitter is as well as how they do it are still present. Ultimately it is designed to suck your time away and keep you engaged in meaningless nonsense. I will keep the account active for a while longer but I likely won’t log in to it. Really I just can’t be bothered to use it at all, even to delete it.

item.title: Having Fun Is Trad
item.description:
It has come to my attention that e-trads have been crusading against fun. Interestingly they do so on the Internet, which is a curious choice of battleground for such a subject. I have absolutely no idea why they are doing this or what they think they will achieve. The most confusing detail of this trend is that having fun is in fact trad so what’s with the intentional friendly fire?

These days people either treat fun as a part of everyday life (which it is), as an excuse to waste their time (addiction cope) or as an evil to be conquered (the cringe take). It’s incredibly strange to see the latter take from people that call themselves ’traditionalists’ as these are the very same people that strive to return to some kind of societal normality. In normal societies people had fun.

History is full of examples of people having fun, be it feasting with friends and neighbors or dancing around a fire or in a ballroom. One could argue that these traditional forms of fun don’t exist anymore, they would be wrong of course. Quite commonly you will find if you try hard to look in the first place that there are plenty of opportunities to do these things already and if that somehow yields zero results for you then the problem is that you aren’t organising it yourself. However this doesn’t explain the aversion to fun that a lot of trads seem to have developed recently.

I think the real problem that some of these people have isn’t people having fun, it’s the ways that people have fun. Particularly the habit forming excesses of it that lead to a loss of enjoyment but an addictive desire that compels participation when any joy to be found is already dead. So is the issue that fun is bad or that having fun is no longer fun? I’d wager it’s the latter.

A good example of habit forming fun is video games, they are formulaic in design, particularly to extract as much of your time as possible. Where is the fun to be found when these video games become a part time (or even a full time) job? If you have to commit yourself to something that used to be possible to just pick up and play you will find yourself drained of enjoyment very quickly.

A major problem with people playing video games is excess. People play them way too much, they revolve their lives around them until they stop being fun and become a chore. They play these video games alone in their bedroom for hours or even days at a time in some cases and what do they get out of it? An ever decreasing dopamine rush when the shiny and sparkly effects flare off when you do the same chore (and that is what a lot of video game content is these days) for the thousandth time.

There’s nothing wrong with having some fun on your own of course, I find myself enjoying a book quite often. Books are trad right?

It’s not just video games that masquerade as fun whilst in actual fact being nothing more than addictive distraction. Television, YouTube, TikTok, etc all fulfill this role as well. Since consumption of these is entirely passive the victims of addiction don’t even need to think about anything.

So let’s make a distinction between fun and distraction.

Fun is when you enjoy yourself. A distraction is when you occupy your time. To quote anti-gambling PSAs “when the fun stops STOP!”.

You don’t owe distractions any of your time, that time belong to you.

Traditionally when someone had free time they spent it with other people, or learning a new skill, reading a book or just getting in some extra rest. Fun was enjoyable in the moment and benefited you in some way as well.

Fun is an ancient and primordial experience that has been twisted and turned into a control mechanism, you can reject it any time you want.

I’m not saying you can’t have fun playing video games, or watching YouTube, etc but you have to be aware that they are built on algorithms and design standards to keep you engaged with them and not with something else. Time is money and they are draining you of it.

At a bare minimum if you want to have fun find a hobby. Dedicate time to it every week, if after a while you don’t enjoy it then find a new one. Repeat this until you are having fun. Don’t fall for the trap of wasting time to pass time.

Your grandfathers went to the pub, the tavern and the mead hall on Thunorsday. You sit on a couch. Who do you think had more fun?

The problem isn’t fun, the problem is a lack of fun.

item.title: A New Path in Life
item.description:
I recently graduated from my Computer Science degree program. I did not enjoy my time on this degree as much as I had hoped when I started. Computers were my passion at one point in the past, but not so much any more. I still enjoy using the skills I developed and researching the industry out of curiousity. Ultimately though I pushed through to finish what I started and was glad when it was over.

But now I am a free man and I am going back into academia to study a completely different field that I am actually passionate for: Archaeology and History. Specifically Celtic and Anglo-Saxon history. Which is the field that I have always wanted to study but was misled by well-meaning and sincere concern over “employability” regarding such a subject. Personally I am not too concerned with the employability of such a degree. Afterall I was led to believe that CompSci would make me a millionaire.

I plan to write about my time on this degree as the subjects themselves are very fascinating but the way that they flow between each other by coincidence is very exciting.

item.title: All About My Meme Diet
item.description:
I’ve been rereading the Unaboomer archives again and came across this interesting post titled “My diet following the memes” and thought it was an interesting read. I recommend reading it if you get the chance.

After reading that post I wanted to make my own post in the same vein, which is this one you are reading now.

Diet or Dogma?

In industrial societies people tend to find themselves identifying with meaningless labels and manmade dogmatic practices to feel unique. You will even find people identifying with silly things like soap brands, whichever soy beverage they consume and even what video game they play.

There are a lot of dogmatic diets out there, some like Paleo are closer to the mark than others. There are other similar meme diets such as Keto too which get the fundamentals right by rejecting the ridiculous food pyramid standard but then fall for the direct consequences of the food pyramid such as so called “nutrition facts” labels and the promotion of factory farmed imported foodstuffs.

A good example of this is many people that have just been introduced to the Keto diet and lazy adherents to it will consider seed oils a perfectly healthy “food” to consume as it has the right macros according to the label. That label is lying of course there are no fats in there, only plant oils. These oils are produced using a highly industrialised and mechanical process involving petroleum byproducts and acetone.

But, at least they get the premise right and if they are coming from the standard Euro-American diet then they are still likely improving their health despite these mistakes.

Fortunately for Keto adherents they do reject the food pyramid and are generally more willing to listen when you have advice to give and generally willing to do at least some research of their own, even if it is second hand research like watching a YouTube video explaining these concepts in normie friendly terms.

On the other hand, there are “diets” that are more or less a suicidal death cult. You know which one it is.

My Diet

I have tried most of these meme diets: Keto, Paleo, Carnivore, etc. They all get the fundamentals right: high fat, high protein. But it isn’t as simple as that. Protein from a plant is not the same and is not comparable at all to protein from an animal.

So I’ve tried the memes, what do I do now? I eat the natural human diet of course. Animal products, nose to tail, dairy, eggs. Raw, rare, cooked, stewed, etc.

I don’t eat bread or other slave foods unless I am eating out with friends or family and I really want to have a burger or something, which is still a meal that contains a lot of animal products. I enjoy fruits that are in season and native to the local soil, I avoid green vegetables and use carrots, potatoes, etc instead but in limited amounts as they are not sustainable for me.

On The Natural Human Diet

The natural human diet consisted of raw meat, fish, perennial fruits and mushrooms. If I was raised in an environment where this wasn’t presented as “disgusting” or “savage” then I would likely be able to adapt to doing it for the entirety of my diet. I would probably enjoy this kind of diet if I was able to break the mental barrier, which is why I include raw meats and organs, dairy and eggs in my diet where possible.

How do I like my steak? Rare with butter and sauteed mushrooms.

item.title: I Dont Care If You Use Linux
item.description:
You may have seen my previous post about Free (as in freedom) software and came to the conclusion that I want to “convert” normies to using Linux. This is not the case.

I do not care if you use Linux or not, I do not care what distro you use either. Whatever works for you, works for you and that’s great.

The reason I recommend that you use a Linux based OS is not that I personally gain from you doing so but that you will gain from it. I have no attachment to what you use or how you use it. Linux fanboyism is a ridiculous concept.

Further Confusion

Regarding the “What Does The Steam Deck mean?” post, someone read it and completely misunderstood it. They were under the impression that I wish to “convert” gamers to Linux. LOL.

I had intended to delete that post for being crap anyway, which I did.

The point I was trying to make could be made in a sentence but I tried to give too much context. So I will make my point here and consider the issue resolved:

The Steam Deck will put more eyes on Linux as a gaming platform. It will not convert the masses to a new operating system that they have no apparent need for. This will not benefit me, I don’t really care.

With that out of the way let’s get to the main point.

I Don’t Care Bro

Simply put if you don’t use Linux I don’t care and more importantly, if you do use Linux I don’t care either.

I have absolutely no need to know or care for what operating system you use.

The Consumer Issue

The advent of Linux consumerism has reached its twilight, we now live in a world where people wear Tux t-shirts unironically and discuss their desktop environment of choice as if it is their favourite sportsball team.

What is a Linux consumer? A Linux‚Ñ¢Ô∏è consumer is someone that doesn’t use Linux because they want a Unix like free software operating system, they are just anti-Windows and use Linux as if it were Windows.

I estimate that about 60-70% of people with a Linux based OS on their personal computer would fall under the category of a Linux consumer and as I stated above. I don’t care.

A typical example is someone that installs whatever meme distro they were shilled then goes on to use Google and Microsoft services, integrating them into every level of their workflow and consumption cycles. It really is an impressive example of cognitive dissonance.

Consuming Linux is a mindset that I just don’t have the time or patience to entertain.

Simply put if you need to attach part of your identity to the operating system that you use, you need to get a life.

Converting Normies

This is simply not an issue.

The only benefit a normie will get from switching to Linux is that their 5 year old laptop won’t run to a halt and can still get security patches. The real normie operating system is Google Chrome after all.

They don’t care about software, ethics, etc. They use their computer to write their homework, read their emails, watch cat videos and buy junk from Amazon. They are content and happy if they can do this, you won’t convince them to change.

“You’re just an elitist!”

Yes.

item.title: Free As In Freedom
item.description:
Libre, not gratis.

I won’t go into the specifics of Free Software in this article, if you would like to know more check the references at the bottom of the page.

Freedom is non-negotiable

Your freedom as a user is the most important aspect of the software that you use.

A common phrase found online regarding services such as search engines and email service providers goes something like “if it’s free then you are the product”. This is a fairly good summary as it implies (accurately) that these service providers see YOU as an extension of their property.

The issue with this statement is the implication that software that is paid for will respect your rights. This is of course not true.

The solution to this problem is straightforward. Don’t use them. I’m not suggesting a boycott (boycotts don’t work lol) I am actually just suggesting that you opt out and choose to use Free Software.

Make a change

The most significant services you can change are:

  • Email Provider
  • Office Suite
  • Operating System
  • Search Engine
  • Web Browser

You should also drop social media and streaming services.

It may seem daunting to have to switch all of your service providers but you don’t need to do it all at once. In fact if you do it slowly over time that is perfectly fine. You may find that you have to do so anyway if you keep on top of sanitising your email inbox, have ongoing projects or need access to a given social media platform to stay in contact with family.

In the latter case you may wish to get them onboard with switching to Free Software and Libre services too!

Every proprietary service you currently use likely has a Free Software equivalent. If it doesn’t then you probably never needed it.

Regarding Video Games and DRM

Video games are almost always proprietary. If you want to play them there are ways to do so on Linux including native Linux binaries. However for those that don’t have native binaries you may experience issues with their “Anti-Cheat” or DRM. I recommend just not buying games that have intrusive layers like that in the first place, it is unacceptable for these companies to treat customers this way.

Stay away from streaming services like Netflix and Spotify. Buy an SD card instead, store your music on that and stick it in your phone. Streaming services take your money and give you nothing in return, you do not own what you “stream” they are ripping you off.

Don’t be fooled

Open Source and Free Software are not the same thing and whilst many Open Source programs would fit the definition of Free Software in practice this is not true of all Open Source programs.

For example, the popular editing suite Visual Studio Code is not free software due to its inclusion of anti-features such as telemetry and centralisation of integrated services.

Another example is Telegram, the client software uses a modified GPL3 that makes it non-free and the server software is completely proprietary. Telegram is fundamentally no different from using WhatsApp in terms of user freedoms and privacy.

A common misconception is that Android devices are “Free” and “Open Source” but this couldn’t be further from the truth. Out of the box these devices do not run Free Software or Open Source software. They run proprietary builds of a semi-open source project but the closed source proprietary nature of the out of the box device makes it a non-free device.

Many of these devices can be modified with Free and Open Source Android forks such as LineageOS and GrapheneOS. With GrapheneOS being the superior choice if you own a Google Pixel device.

I’m happy to help

If you would like advice or some pointers or if you would like to discuss the topics discussed here feel free to contact me.

I will likely publish articles on switching services in the future so make sure to subscribe to the RSS.

References:

  • What is Free Software? | GNU
  • Why I Use the GPL and Not Cuck Licenses | Luke Smith
  • Free As In Freedom: Richard Stallman’s Crusade For Free Software, Sam Williams - ISBN-13: 978-0-59-600287-4
